children.name: üéØ Features
children.description: v1.1 UPDATE: Documentation and assessment of all TreeListy capabilities. Each feature area contains Current state, honest Assessment, and specific Improvements. NEW: Added usage frequency estimates (High/Medium/Low).

children.name: Views
children.description: TreeListy's 5 visualization modes: Tree, Canvas, 3D, Gantt, and Calendar.

children.name: Current
children.description:
**Tree View** [Usage: HIGH]: Classic outliner with expand/collapse, drag-drop reordering, keyboard navigation (j/k/h/l), inline editing. Primary editing interface.

**Canvas View** [Usage: MEDIUM]: GoJS-powered 2D visualization with draggable nodes, dependency lines, minimap, zoom/pan. Best for visual overview.

**3D View** [Usage: LOW]: Three.js WebGL renderer showing tree as 3D structure with orbit controls. Novelty/demo value.

**Gantt View** [Usage: MEDIUM]: Frappe Gantt integration for timeline visualization with critical path highlighting. PM-focused.

**Calendar View** [Usage: LOW]: Monthly calendar grid for date-based items. Limited functionality.

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Strengths**: View diversity is a major differentiator vs Notion (1 view), Workflowy (1 view), Roam (2 views). Canvas dependency visualization unique. Gantt is production-quality.

**Weaknesses**: 3D view is novelty without clear use case. Canvas performance degrades at ~150-200 nodes (observed, not benchmarked). Calendar lacks week/day views.

**vs Competition**: More views than any competitor. But each view less polished than single-view specialists.

children.name: Improvements
children.description:
1. Add virtual scrolling to Tree view
2. Improve Canvas performance
3. Add week/day views to Calendar
4. Rethink 3D view purpose
5. Add view transition animations
6. Add view recommendation
7. Keyboard shortcuts for views

children.name: Patterns
children.description: 21 domain-specific schemas that transform generic trees into specialized tools.

children.name: Current
children.description:
21 Patterns Available [Usage by category]:
- HIGH: generic, roadmap, thesis
- MEDIUM: philosophy, sales, book, lifetree
- LOW: film, veo3, sora2, course, fitness, event, strategy, familytree, dialogue, gmail, filesystem, freespeech, custom

Pattern Translation Engine preserves shadow data when switching patterns.

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Strengths**: Pattern variety enables diverse use cases. Shadow data preservation is technically elegant.

**Weaknesses**: Pattern selection overwhelming (21 options with no guidance). Estimated <20% of patterns ever used. No usage analytics to validate. No custom pattern creation.

**vs Competition**: Unique feature - competitors don't have domain-specific schemas. But discoverability poor.

children.name: Improvements
children.description: Add pattern wizard. Create custom pattern builder. Show shadow data indicator.

children.name: AI Integration
children.description: TreeBeard assistant with Claude/Gemini/ChatGPT backends, Research mode, and MCP Bridge.

children.name: Current
children.description:
**TreeBeard** [Usage: HIGH for users who discover it]:
- Quick mode: JSON command responses
- Deep mode: Natural language conversation
- Multi-backend: Claude (primary), Gemini, ChatGPT
- Research mode: Web search integration

**MCP Bridge** [Usage: LOW - developer-only]:
- Bidirectional Claude Code CLI communication
- Chrome extension integration for Gmail/Drive/Calendar
- Task queue with inbox review

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Strengths**: MCP Bridge is architecturally innovative - enables web service access through user's browser session. Multi-backend flexibility.

**Weaknesses**: No streaming responses (jarring wait). MCP setup complexity (~10 steps) limits to developers only. API key management fragmented.

**vs Competition**: Notion has AI but no CLI integration. Roam has no AI. TreeListy's MCP Bridge is unique but inaccessible.

children.name: Improvements
children.description: Add response streaming. Unify API key management. Add MCP Bridge setup wizard.

children.name: Collaboration
children.description: Firebase Live Sync and Cloud Share.

children.name: Current
children.description:
**Firebase Live Sync** [Usage: LOW - rarely used]:
- Real-time collaborative editing
- Room-based sessions with 6-char codes
- Jitsi Meet voice chat integration

**Cloud Share** [Usage: MEDIUM]:
- Short URLs for large trees (>8KB)
- Firebase-backed sharing
- Lite Share strips descriptions

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Strengths**: Live sync works when used. Zero-config joining (just paste code).

**Weaknesses**: No conflict resolution - last write wins. No permission levels (all editors equal). No presence indicators. No user identity.

**vs Competition**: Notion has robust multi-user with permissions. Roam has multiplayer with user attribution. TreeListy's collab is MVP-level.

children.name: Improvements
children.description: Add CRDT. Add optional authentication. Implement permission levels.

children.name: Data Management
children.description: Import/Export, 50-state undo, LocalStorage auto-save.

children.name: Current
children.description:

- JSON [HIGH] - primary format
- Excel [MEDIUM] - business users
- MS Project XML [LOW] - PM migration
- PDF [LOW] - RAG extraction
- Text/Voice [LOW] - experimental

**Export** [Usage: HIGH]:

**Storage**:

- 50-state undo stack

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Strengths**: Import variety covers most sources. Auto-save prevents data loss. Undo is generous (50 states).

**Weaknesses**: Export limited to JSON only - no Excel/PDF/HTML. Single-tree storage forces manual file management. LocalStorage 5MB limit.

**vs Competition**: Notion exports to Markdown/PDF/HTML. Workflowy has OPML. TreeListy export is weakest point.

children.name: Improvements

**vs Competition**: Notion mobile is native app (better). Workflowy mobile is fast (smaller). TreeListy PWA is impressive but rough.

children.name: üèóÔ∏è Architecture
children.description: v1.1 UPDATE: Technical documentation of how TreeListy is built. NEW: Performance benchmarks and code complexity metrics added where measurable.

children.name: Single-File Structure
children.description: ~1.3MB HTML file containing all HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

children.name: Current
children.description:
**File Structure** (treeplexity.html):
- Total: ~70,000 lines, 1.3MB
- HTML: Lines 1-2000 (~2,000 lines)
- CSS: Lines 2000-10000 (~8,000 lines)
- JavaScript: Lines 10000-70000+ (~60,000 lines)

**Load Performance**:
- First paint: ~800ms (cached), ~2.5s (uncached)
- Full interactive: ~1.5s (cached), ~4s (uncached)
- Tested on 2023 MacBook Pro, Chrome 120

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Strengths**: Zero build complexity - edit and deploy. No bundler/transpiler bugs. Single source of truth.

**Weaknesses**:
- 1.3MB initial load impacts mobile (4G: ~5-8s)
- IDE struggles: VS Code slows at 60k+ lines
- Claude Code context: Can't load full file
- No tree-shaking - all code loads always

**Complexity Metrics** (estimated):
- Cyclomatic complexity: HIGH (many nested conditions)
- Function count: ~500+
- Global variables: ~50+

children.name: Improvements
children.description: Add code splitting. Add TypeScript via JSDoc. Minify for production.

children.name: Core Data Model
children.description: capexTree object structure, node schema, hyperedges.

children.name: Current
children.description:
**capexTree Structure**:
```javascript
{
  id: "root",
  name: string,
  pattern: { key, labels },
  hyperedges: [...],
  children: [phases]
}
```

**Hierarchy**: root ‚Üí phase ‚Üí item ‚Üí subtask (4 levels)
**Node fields**: id, name, type, description, expanded, pattern-specific fields
**Hyperedges**: Cross-cutting node groups stored at root level

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Strengths**: JSON-serializable - easy export/import. Simple mental model. Hyperedges enable cross-cutting views.

**Weaknesses**:
- 4-level limit is artificial (could be N-level)
- No schema validation - silent corruption possible
- Node IDs are timestamp-based, not UUIDs
- No referential integrity checks

**Performance**: Tree traversal O(n) for n nodes. No indexing.

children.name: Improvements
children.description: Remove 4-level limit. Add schema validation. Use UUIDs for node IDs.

children.name: Rendering Pipeline
children.description: Five render functions for each view.

children.name: Current
children.description:
**Five Render Functions**:
- `render()` - Tree view (~400 lines)
- `renderCanvas()` - Canvas/GoJS (~800 lines)
- `render3D()` - Three.js (~600 lines)
- `renderGantt()` - Frappe Gantt (~300 lines)
- `renderCalendar()` - Calendar grid (~200 lines)

Total rendering code: ~2,300 lines

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Performance Observations** (not formal benchmarks):
- Tree view: Smooth up to ~500 nodes
- Canvas view: Noticeable lag at ~150-200 nodes
- 3D view: Frame drops at ~100 nodes
- Gantt view: Smooth up to ~200 tasks

**Weaknesses**:
- Full re-render on every change (no diffing)
- No virtualization (all nodes in DOM)
- renderCanvas() is 800+ lines - hard to maintain
- GoJS dependency adds ~500KB

children.name: Improvements
children.description: Implement virtual scrolling. Add render diffing. Batch renders.

children.name: State Management
children.description: Global variables, saveState() for undo.

children.name: Current
children.description:
**State Variables** (global scope):
- `capexTree` - Main tree data
- `viewMode` - Current view (tree/canvas/3d/gantt/calendar)
- `selectedNode` - Currently selected node ID
- `undoStack` / `redoStack` - 50-state history
- `firebaseSyncState` - Collaboration session
- ~50+ other globals

**Persistence**: LocalStorage with JSON.stringify

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Strengths**: Simple mental model - everything is global. Easy debugging (inspect window.capexTree). saveState() is explicit.

**Weaknesses**:
- Global state is unpredictable - any function can modify
- Race conditions possible with async operations
- No change detection - must call render() manually
- Memory: 50 full tree copies in undo stack

**Technical Debt**: HIGH - would require major refactor to fix

children.name: Improvements
children.description: Implement reactive state. Add state schema. Use Immer.

children.name: External Integrations
children.description: Netlify, Firebase, MCP Bridge, CDN libraries.

children.name: Current
children.description:
**Netlify**:
- Hosting: Static files from GitHub
- Functions: claude-proxy.js for API calls
- Cold start: ~500ms for first function call

**Firebase**:
- Realtime Database for live sync
- Short URL storage for Cloud Share
- Anonymous auth (no user accounts)

**MCP Bridge**:
- WebSocket server (Node.js)
- Chrome extension for web service access
- packages/treelisty-mcp-bridge/

**CDN Libraries**: GoJS, Three.js, Frappe Gantt, marked.js

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Strengths**: Netlify is reliable and fast. Firebase handles real-time well. MCP Bridge is architecturally elegant.

**Weaknesses**:
- Netlify cold starts: 500ms+ on first AI call
- Firebase rules are permissive (anyone can read/write with room code)
- CDN dependency: GoJS/Three.js failures break views
- No fallbacks if CDN fails

**Security Concern**: Firebase rules should be tightened

children.name: Improvements
children.description: Add rate limiting. Improve Firebase security. Bundle critical libraries.

children.name: Build & Deploy
children.description: GitHub, Netlify auto-deploy, manual versioning.

children.name: Current
children.description:
**Deployment Pipeline**:
1. Edit treeplexity.html
2. Update version in 4 locations
3. git push to main
4. Netlify auto-deploys (~90s)

**Testing**:
- 385+ Playwright unit tests
- Manual smoke testing
- No CI/CD pipeline

**Versioning**: Manual in 4 locations (error-prone)

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Strengths**: Instant deploy - push and live in 90s. No build step failures. Simple mental model.

**Weaknesses**:
- Manual version bumping in 4 places - often forgotten
- No CI/CD - tests run locally only
- No branch protection - can push broken code to main
- No staging environment
- No rollback mechanism (must revert commit)

**Risk**: HIGH - easy to deploy bugs to production

children.name: Improvements
children.description: Automate version bumping. Add GitHub Actions CI. Enable branch protection.

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Impact Analysis**:

- **Performance blocks real usage**: Users with 200+ node projects hit walls. Canvas becomes unusable. Forces artificial tree splitting.

- **Silent failures erode trust**: No error messages when things fail. Users don't know if save worked. LocalStorage quota exceeded silently.

- **Missing basics frustrate**: No find/replace is inexcusable for a text tool. No bulk operations wastes time.

**Persona Impact**:
- PM: Can't use for real projects (too slow)
- Researcher: Can't manage large knowledge bases
- Student: Fine for thesis (small scale)

children.name: Improvements

- **View-switching strategy**: Tree for editing, Canvas for overview, Gantt for scheduling.

- **AI collaboration**: TreeBeard for expansion, Research for web data, MCP for automation.

- **Hyperedge thinking**: Group related items across hierarchy.

children.name: Assessment
children.description:
**Expert Limitations**:

- **Scale limits**: Even experts hit performance walls at ~200 nodes
- **No async collaboration**: Can't leave comments for team review
- **No macros/automation**: Repetitive tasks must be manual
- **No plugin system**: Can't extend functionality
- **No public API**: Can't integrate with other tools

**Expert Workarounds**:
- Split large trees manually
- Use MCP Bridge for automation (developers only)
- Export JSON and process externally
